channel.title: Posts on Abby Post's Github Site
channel.description: Recent content in Posts on Abby Post's Github Site

item.title: Who in the Big Ten Can Compare to Standout Caitlin Clark?
item.description: Whether you watch women’s college basketball or not, if you’re a sports fan you most likely know the name Caitlin Clark. Clark is a basketball player at the University of Iowa. The sophomore guard with her incredible shooting ability and quick decision making skills has made herself a name in college basketball. During the 2021-2022 season she won many honors including National Player of the week four different times, and Big Ten Player of the Year.

item.title: Was the Husker Women's Basketball Team Worthy of Earning a Spot in the Top 25?
item.description: The Nebraska women’s basketball team had a season unlike any of its recent years. Many deemed it “special” with the success they had. Starting the year off with a 12-0 record, Nebraska had built up its confidence heading into Big Ten play. Led by Amy Williams the Huskers completed their season 24-9 with a trip to the NCAA tournament as an 8th seed. One thing the Husker team couldn’t mark off of its list of accomplishments was making it into the AP Top 25 Poll.

item.title: Hello R Markdown
item.description: R Markdown This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com. You can embed an R code chunk like this: summary(cars) ## speed dist ## Min. : 4.0 Min. : 2.00 ## 1st Qu.:12.0 1st Qu.: 26.00 ## Median :15.0 Median : 36.00 ## Mean :15.4 Mean : 42.98 ## 3rd Qu.

item.title: A Plain Markdown Post
item.description: This is a post written in plain Markdown (*.md) instead of R Markdown (*.Rmd). The major differences are: You cannot run any R code in a plain Markdown document, whereas in an R Markdown document, you can embed R code chunks (```{r}); A plain Markdown post is rendered through Blackfriday, and an R Markdown document is compiled by rmarkdown and Pandoc. There are many differences in syntax between Blackfriday’s Markdown and Pandoc’s Markdown.
